review.title: Nominals, Inverses, Counting, and Conjunctive Queries or: Why Infinity is your Friend!
review.abstract: Description Logics are knowledge representation formalisms that provide, for example, the logical underpinning of the W3C OWL standards. Conjunctive queries, the standard query language in databases, have recently gained significant attention as an expressive formalism for querying Description Logic knowledge bases. Several different techniques for deciding conjunctive query entailment are available for a wide range of DLs. Nevertheless, the combination of nominals, inverse roles, and number restrictions in OWL 1 and OWL 2 DL causes unsolvable problems for the techniques hitherto available. We tackle this problem and present a decidability result for entailment of unions of conjunctive queries in the DL ALCHOIQb that contains all three problematic constructors simultaneously. Provided that queries contain only simple roles, our result also shows decidability of entailment of (unions of) conjunctive queries in the logic that underpins OWL 1 DL and we believe that the presented results will pave the way for further progress towards conjunctive query entailment decision procedures for the Description Logics underlying the OWL standards.

metadata.title: Nominals, Inverses, Counting, and Conjunctive Queries or: Why Infinity is your Friend!

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: The first report on cyclical queries as a main topic is therefore given by Calvanese, De Giacomo, and Lenzerini (1998a). Particularly in recent years, the problem of the decidability of cyclical queries and the complexity of the problem has been discussed in different logic. (Glimm, Horrocks, Lutz, & Sattler, 2008a; Glimm, Horrocks, & Sattler, 2008a; Glimm, Horrocks, & Sattler, 2008b; Lutz, Eiter, Ortiz, & Simkus, 2009). Conjunctive query is already present in the relatively weak DL ALCI (Lutz, 2008), which was initially attributed to inverse roles.

sections.heading: 1.2 Contributions and Overview
sections.text: In view of all these results, which show a great interest in the problem of the cyclical survey.

sections.heading: 2. The Big Picture
sections.text: Before going into the technical details, we will describe our general line of reasoning that defines the decideability of conjunctural query results in ALCHOIQb.

sections.heading: 2.1 Decidability via Finitely Representable Countermodels
sections.text: Let K be an ALCHOIQb knowledge base and let q be the subjunctive query in question, i.e. we aim to determine whether K | = q.Sure, since ALCHOIQb is a fragment of first-order predicate logic with equality, K can be translated into a FOL sentence FOL (K). Likewise, we find that a FOL sentence FOL (q) forq is only an existentially quantified formula. Therefore, the consequences of a finite FOL theory can be recursively enumerated, which provides us with a procedure that ends when K | = q. Therefore, we can establish decisiveness by providing another algorithm that terminates the equalization above - i.e., if there is a word called so that we can build a counter-model for any word.

sections.heading: 2.2 Finite Representability by Bounding Nominals and Blocking
sections.text: We will now outline how we will show that there is always an infinitely representable counter-model, if there is one at all. We do this by taking any counter-model and carefully transforming it into an infinitely representable counter-model. Cautiously, this means that we must ensure that the transformation preserves the two properties that 1) are a model of the underlying knowledge base K and 2) are not the eligible query q. The result of the total transformation will be a regular model, i.e. a structure in which substructures are periodically repeated in a certain sense. In DL theory, it is common practice to construct this type of model from arbitrary by blocking techniques, recognizing certain element configurations that occur twice in the original model and generating the new model by endlessly stringing together the same sub-structure that is limited by these two configurations. In the case we are looking at, this technique cannot be applied directly to the original counter-model.

sections.heading: 2.3 Bounding Nominals by Transformations of Forest Quasi-Models
sections.text: Returning to this concession, they have a real forest structure that is easier to handle and manipulate. We use two techniques to turn "real" models into quasi-models and vice versa: A model can be unraveled and yields a quasi-forest model. A quasi-forest model can be broken down to obtain a "real" model. Both techniques retain certain structural characteristics. Our strategy to construct a counter-model with an endless number of nominals consists of the following three steps: • Take an arbitrary counter-model and unravel it. • Transform the obtained quasi-model by replacing critical parts with well-preserved ones • Collapse the obtained structure into a (proper) model. The mentioned "critical parts" are those that lead to new denominations. They must - at least to a large extent - be avoided.

sections.heading: 3. Preliminaries
sections.text: We first define the syntax and semantics of roles and then move on to SHOIQb concepts, individuals and knowledge bases. We do not use the full expressivity of SHOIQb, but it is a handy screen for all DLs we work with, and we can define less expressive DLs of interest than restrictions of SHOIQb. We call S = (NC, NR, NI) a signature. sections.heading: 3.1 Conjunctive Queries and Unions of Conjunctive Queries
sections.text: We ask Boolean conjunctural questions because they are the basic form of questions we deal with. We also define non-Boolean questions later and show how they can be reduced to Boolean questions. Finally, conjunctural questions are only a disjuncture of conjunctural knowledge composed of NC, NR, and NI. A term t is an element of NV, NI, and NI. Let's be a term of NC, NR, and NI that replaces a signature and an infinite set of variables composed of NC, NR, and NI. A term t is an element of NI. Let's be a term of NC that is a roll name, and t is an expression A (t) or r (t), and we refer to these two types of atoms as concept atoms and role atoms respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2 Simplifying Assumptions
sections.text: In the following, we make several assumptions that are without loss of generality, but simplify the presentation of the decision-making processes on the basics of knowledge. (However, this is only possible if the knowledge base is replaced by ALCOIFb knowledge bases.) Nevertheless, we also consider our results to be SHOIFb knowledge and queries with only simple roles in the query and ALCHOIQb knowledge bases, i.e. if the knowledge base contains secure Boolean role expressions, but no transitivity. Restricting to ALCOIFb knowledge is without loss of generality, as we show now.Provided the query contains only simple roles, we can use the elimination techniques for transitivity (Kazakov & Motik, 2008) to reduce a SHOIQ knowledge base to anALCHOIQ knowledge with extended signature.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Connected and Constant-free Queries
sections.text: We assume that questions are connected. Specifically, let q be a subjunctive query. We say that q is connected to q if there is a sequence t1 for all t, t, c, term (q)..., tn so that t1 = t, tn = t ² and for all 1 ≤ i < n, there is a role name r so that r (ti, ti + 1) q or r (ti + 1, ti) q. a collection q1,.., qn of queries is a division of q if q = q1,..., Term (qi) and Term (qj) that Term (qj) is associated with 1 ≤ i < j ≤ n, and each Qi. Let K be a knowledge base, q a subjunctive query, and q1 Junk, and q1 that we assume that the subjunctive query is variable..., qn a division of qi.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 General Notation
sections.text: Unless otherwise specified, we use A and B for concept names; C and D for potentially complex concepts; r and s for roles; f for functional or inverse function roles; U and V for secure Boolean role expressions; and o for nomenclatures used in TBox axioms or occurring in complex concepts. Subscripts and superscripts may be appended. Unless otherwise specified, we use q (possibly with subscriptions) for a connected Boolean subjunctive query, K for a simplified ALCOIFb knowledge base, I for an interpretation (х I, · I), and π, µ for ratings.

sections.heading: 4. Model Construction
sections.text: However, the main idea of a forest is very weak, as we also allow arbitrary relationships between tree elements and roots. Without such relationships, we call the result a strict forest form. We do not exploit the beautiful characteristics of trees and forests in the following sections, when we replace parts in interpretations that lead to an infinite number of new denominations. Since even models of an ALCOIFb knowledge base that have a kind of forest shape are not really forests, we also present "approximations" of models in which nominations are no longer interpreted as singleton sets. We call these structures quasi-interpretations or such interpretations may take the form of real forests. Furthermore, we offer a way of "unraveling" an arbitrary model into a forest that is a quasi-model for the knowledge base and a kind of "collapse" of such forest models back into real models of the knowledge base.

sections.heading: 5. Quasi-Entailment in Quasi-Models
sections.text: In this section, we will make a characterization of the forests, which means a certain selection for the corresponding "proper models." In our further argument, we will talk about the initial part of a tree, that is, the part that remains when the branches are reduced to a specified length. The following problem ensures that in the case of purified models, we only find endless inextricable trees of depth that "look different." Let K be a consistent knowledge base. Then, there is a purified interpretation, which I interpret to mean that I and, for each n, there are only infinite non-isomorphic trees of depth.

sections.heading: 6. Limits and Forest Transformations
sections.text: Before challenging the following constructions, we will attempt to provide some high-level explanations to convey the intuition behind the steps that follow. As already mentioned, one of the main obstacles to a conjunctive query decision process is that it can be identified by linking it to a "correct nominal system." However, we will show that for any model of a knowledge base that does not satisfy a conjunctive query (i.e., for each countermodel there is a "nice" countermodel with only an infinite number of new denominations (in the following section, we will argue that this ensures the existence of a process that does not question the query through the knowledge base).

sections.heading: 7. Finite Representations of Models
sections.text: In this section, we will show how to construct a finite representation of a forest model into an expanded knowledge base that only has a finite number of roots. We will then show that these finite representations can be used to verify the effects of cultivation. To do this, we will use a technique that is very similar to the blocking techniques used in our forest models (see, for example, Horrocks & Sattler, 2007).A tableau algorithm builds a so-called completion graph that represents a finite representation of a model. A completion diagram has essentially the same structure as our forest quasimodels. It contains root nodes for the nominal use of the knowledge employed plus additional root nodes for new denominations that begin BCPs. Each (new and old) nominal is the root of a tree, and relationships occur only between direct neighbors within a tree, between elements within a tree and a root, or between roots.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text: We have shown that the problem can be resolved by providing a decision-making process and demonstrating its correctness. As the approach is purely a decision-making process, the arithmetic complexity of the problem remains open. Our finding also shows that the decision-making ability of conjunctive query mergers in SHOIQ and SROIQ (underlying OWL DL and OWL 2), if we do not reject simple roles as binary queries, has reached a first important milestone towards addressing the problem of conjunctive queries for OWL 1 DL and OWL 2.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: During his stay in Oxford, where our collaboration began, Sebastian Rudolph was supported by a scholarship of the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD). Further work on this topic was made possible by the funding of the ExpresST project of the German Research Foundation (DFG). Birte Glimm was supported by the EPSRC in the project HermiT: Reasoning with Large Ontologies.We thank the three anonymous reviewers for their numerous helpful comments. We thank Ian Pratt-Hartmann for (unconsciously) smashing our graphhomates, Maria Magdalena Ortiz de la Fuente for creating the competitive atmosphere, Yevgeny Kasakov for breathtaking discussions about black holes, Boris Motik for his motivating reflections on the value of academic life and last but not least God for providing exceptional weather and - above all - infinity.

referenceMentions.context: The underlying reasoning problems are well-understood, and the computational complexity of the standard reasoning tasks given a knowledge base as input range from PTime-complete for DLs with limited expresivity such as DL-Lite (Calvanese, De Giacomo, Lembo, Lenzerini, & Rosati, 2005), EL (Baader, 2003), and ELP (Krötzsch, Rudolph, & Hitzler, 2008) to 2-NExpTime-complete for very expressive DLs such as SROIQ (Kazakov, 2008).

, biology (Sidhu, Dillon, Chang, & Sidhu, 2005), bio informatics (Wolstencroft, Brass, Horrocks, Lord, Sattler, Turi, & Stevens, 2005), medicine (Golbreich, Zhang, & Bodenreider, 2006), information integration (Calvanese, De Giacomo, Lenzerini, Nardi, & Rosati, 1998b), geography (Goodwin, 2005), geology (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 2006), defense (Lacy, Aviles, Fraser, Gerber, Mulvehill, & Gaskill, 2005), and configuration (McGuinness & Wright, 1998).
Modal and Description Logics (Grädel, 2001; Vardi, 1997) and we also heavily exploit a variant of this property to establish our decidability result.
Modal and Description Logics (Grädel, 2001; Vardi, 1997) and we also heavily exploit a variant of this property to establish our decidability result.

For the DLs SHIQ and SHOQ decidability and 2-ExpTime-completeness of the problem is known (Glimm, Horrocks, Lutz, & Sattler, 2008a; Glimm, Horrocks, & Sattler, 2008b; Lutz, 2008; Eiter, Lutz, Ortiz, & Simkus, 2009).
Conjunctive query entailment is already 2-ExpTime-hard in the relatively weak DL ALCI (Lutz, 2008), which was initially attributed to inverse roles.
Recently, it was shown, however, that also transitive roles together with role hierarchies as in the DL SH make conjunctive query entailment 2-ExpTime-hard (Eiter et al., 2009).
In particular the most recent extension (Calvanese et al., 2009) is very close to a conjunctive query entailment decision procedure for OWL 2, which corresponds to the DL SROIQ, because it covers
, 2008a) and this holds also for CQ entailment in the two variable guarded fragment with counting (Pratt-Hartmann, 2009).
Query entailment and answering have also been studied in the context of databases with incomplete information (Rosati, 2006b; van der Meyden, 1998; Grahne, 1991).

Another tractable DL is EL (Baader, 2003). Conjunctive query entailment in EL is, however, not tractable as the complexity increases to coNP-complete (Rosati, 2007b). Moreover for EL++ (Baader et al., 2005), a still tractable extension of EL, query entailment is even undecidable (Krötzsch, Rudolph, & Hitzler, 2007). This is mainly because in EL++, one can use unrestricted role compositions. This allows for encoding context-free languages, and conjunctive queries can then be used to check the intersection of such languages, which is known to be an undecidable problem. Since the logics used in databases with incomplete information are considerable less expressive than ALCHOIQb, the techniques developed in that area do not transfer to our setting. Given that query entailment is a (computationally) harder task than, for example, knowledge base satisfiability, it is not very surprising that decidability of the latter task does not necessarily transfer to the problem of CQ entailment. Most of the undecidability results can be transferred from FOL since many DLs can directly be translated into an equivalent FOL theory. For example, it is known that conjunctive query entailment is undecidable in the two variable fragment of First-Order Logic L2 (Rosati, 2007a), and Rosati identifies a relatively small set of constructors that cause the undecidability (most notably role negation axioms, i.e., axioms of the form ∀x, y (¬R(x, y)→ P (x, y)) for R,P binary predicates). Pratt-Hartmann (2009) recently established decidability for CQ entailment in the two variable guarded fragment with counting (GC2).
Meanwhile also alternative approaches such as resolution (Kazakov & Motik, 2008), and hypertableau-based procedures (Motik et al., 2009) are available and implemented.
As a result of the completeness theorem for FOL (Gödel, 1929), the consequences of a finite FOL theory are recursively enumerable, which provides us with a procedure that terminates if K |= q.

A proof is given by Tessaris (2001) and, with this lemma, it is clear that the restriction to connected queries is indeed without loss of generality since entailment of q can be decided by checking entailment of each qi at a time.

This is also the reason why the tableau algorithm for entailment of conjunctive queries with only simple roles in the query of Calvanese et al. (2009) is sound, complete, and terminating on SHIQ, SHOQ, and SHOI knowledge bases, but is not guaranteed to terminate on SHOIQ knowledge bases (transitivity, i.
The proof is essentially as the one by Ortiz et al. (2008a), but adapted to our case, where we work completely on interpretations.

metadata.abstractText: Description Logics are knowledge representation formalisms that provide, for example, the logical underpinning of the W3C OWL standards. Conjunctive queries, the standard query language in databases, have recently gained significant attention as an expressive formalism for querying Description Logic knowledge bases. Several different techniques for deciding conjunctive query entailment are available for a wide range of DLs. Nevertheless, the combination of nominals, inverse roles, and number restrictions in OWL 1 and OWL 2 DL causes unsolvable problems for the techniques hitherto available. We tackle this problem and present a decidability result for entailment of unions of conjunctive queries in the DL ALCHOIQb that contains all three problematic constructors simultaneously. Provided that queries contain only simple roles, our result also shows decidability of entailment of (unions of) conjunctive queries in the logic that underpins OWL 1 DL and we believe that the presented results will pave the way for further progress towards conjunctive query entailment decision procedures for the Description Logics underlying the OWL standards.
